variant.question: What classification is given to a multi-engine turbo-jet aircraft aircraft with less than 9 passenger seats and a weight less than 5700kgs?

options.text: Class a
class c
unclassified
class b

variant.question:
Fuel loaded onto an aeroplane is 15 400 kg but is erroneously entered into the load and trim sheet as 14 500 kg.
 This error is not detected by the flight crew but they will notice that

options.text: speed at un-stick will be higher than expected.
V1 will be increased.
the aeroplane will rotate much earlier than expected.
V1 will be reached sooner than expected.

variant.question:
Due to a mistake in the load sheet the aeroplane is 100 kg heavier than you believe it to be
As a consequence

options.text: VMU will be higher.
VR will be higher.
V1 VMU VR will all occur earlier.
V1 will be higher.

variant.question: A performance class B aeroplane in the light wake turbulence category can have a maximum operational passenger seating configuration of ___ and a maximum take-off mass of ___ or less.

An airline operator shall make sure that if the aircraft planned for the flight is a performance class B aeroplane, it will be able, throughout its flight route or its alternate route scheduled from this initial route, to reach a climb rate of at least:

options.text: 300 ft/min with all engines operating at maximum continuous power.
300 ft/min with one engine inoperative and all the others operating at maximum continuous power.
500 ft/min with one engine inoperative and all the others operating at maximum continuous power.
500 ft/min with all engines operating at maximum cruise power.

variant.question: An airline operator shall make sure that if the aircraft planned for the flight is a performance class B aeroplane, it will be able, throughout its flight route or its alternate route scheduled from this initial route, to reach a climb rate of at least

options.text: 300 ft/min with all engines operating at maximum continuous power.
500 ft/min with all engines operating at maximum cruise power.
500 ft/min with one engine inoperative and all the others operating at maximum continuous power.
300 ft/min with one engine inoperative and all the others operating at maximum continuous power.

variant.question: What aircraft state will lead to the greatest control difficulties?

options.text: One engine failed and full thrust on the live engine.
An aircraft at VMC with 2 engines at idle power
One engine failed and idle thrust on the live engine.
An aircraft flying at VMC

variant.question: A pilot of a single-engined turbine aeroplane performs a Commercial Air Transport flight with passengers over land with no significant terrain and the cruise phase will be above a solid layer of cloud. The planned route must be such that, in the event of an engine failure, the aeroplane is able to glide...

options.text: to a point 1000 ft above a suitable landing area and the bottom of any solid cloud layer should be above the minimum safe altitude.
to the point of landing on a suitable landing site and there should be no cloud below a height of 1000 ft agl.
from an altitude where the rate of climb is at least 300 fpm to a point 1000 ft above a runway, onto which a successful landing can be made.
to a point 1000 ft above a runway onto which a successful emergency landing can be made and there should be no cloud below the minimum safe altitude.

variant.question: A jet transport aeroplane at a cruise altitude of FL370 suffers a loss of cabin pressurisation without structural damage. - The crew should initially descend at...

options.text: MMO (maximum operating Mach number), and airbrakes can be extended to increase the rate of descent if necessary.
1.32 VMD (minimum drag speed), and airbrakes and/or flaps may be extended to increase the rate of descent if necessary.
VMO (maximum operating speed), and airbrakes can be extended to increase the rate of descent if necessary.
the speed for L/DMAX (maximum lift-to-drag ratio), and airbrakes and/or flaps may be extended to increase the rate of descent if necessary.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying in heavy rain. To carry out a safe approach, it is necessary to:

options.text: increase its approach speed, because the rain affects the lift by deteriorating the boundary layer.
carry out an approach with flaps up, in order to avoid exposing too much lifting surface to the rain.
reduce the approach speed, because the runway may be very slippery on landing.
maintain the normal approach speed up to landing.

variant.question: For a Performance Class A turbo-propeller powered aeroplane on a commercial flight, a 2200 m long runway at the destination aerodrome is expected to be wet. It must be ensured that the landing mass of the aeroplane allows a full stop landing on a dry runway within a landing distance of...
